text: I'm Scott day I'm chief technology
officer at sound exchange I'm
responsible for everything related to
our information technology everything
from our IT infrastructure to our
software engineering our development
operations and project management sound
exchange is a independent organization
not for profit that was created by the
some US copyright legislation that got
passed in the 1990s and basically we're
the sole US entity to collect and
distribute royalties related to the
performance of sound recordings and a
number of digital services in the u.s.
when I started in you know kind of late
2011 we were trying to figure out how
we're gonna transform the technology
platform as well as achieve some
business goals which was to expand
beyond our core mission kind of
diversify our source of royalties that
we were collecting and distributing
we needed to reduce the technology drag
that was kind of kind of slowing our
progress and ultimately we needed to do
in the most efficient reliable rapid
fast way we can do that I mean as a
non-profit any any of our expenses
essentially take out from the ultimate
recipient of the royalties so we were
trying to make sure that our you know
the our administrative costs were as low
as possible and continued to stay as low
as possible so we started with a very
small step which was our corporate
website and said you know it's printed
it doesn't connect anything else
it was self-contained and we thought we
would learn a lot in that process and
then if it we had problems it was
relatively low risk for us and and that
went very quickly we essentially think
over the course of a day or two just to
head it up and running on on AWS using
ec2 for compute and s3 for storage and
you know some of the networking
infrastructure and that allowed us to
you know start learning and then you
know we started adding capabilities to
there you know the elastic load
balancing and auto scaling we just kept
adding from there and then as we are
starting this this rather large
strategic and business initiative to
basically build a brand new platform to
kind of transform to this new platform
we said let's see if we can't leverage
AWS and the cloud as we go through you
know building out the new systems and
essentially as as we've brought on new
and newer
components for this overall new platform
each of them have been launched on AWS
in terms of what we're running on AWS
it's it started like I said with our
websites a machines comm but now it's
pretty much our our core business
processes and our core royalty
administration platform is all in AWS
and we it's a there are six back-end
systems that are kind of doing the hard
work and then we have a number of
front-end either internally facing or
externally facing customer portals and
applications that are built on top of
that we think they're sky's the limit in
terms of if there is a copyrighted item
that has a usage base charge or royalty
associated with it we've got we believe
a flexible enough platform to be able to
support that and and we've got the scale
now that we've got everything on and on
the cloud so we are shifting our focus
you know a bit and expanding so that
we're diversifying trying to diversify
our royalties that we collect expanding
beyond the core mission into new
business areas and we feel like we're
well positioned to pursue that
